title: How to talk as if you are writing - Quora

response.answer_text: Why would you ever want to talk as if you were writing? In writing, sentences are longer and more complicated. The modern use of “participle phrases” would be distinctive: “Going to the store, I will be buying milk.” Embedded modifiers would also be distinctive. “I’m going to the store, Walmart, and then to work.” Putting dialogue tags after the quote (or within) would be very distinctive. “I don’t know where Jane is, but ‘I’m coming’ she said.” Obviously, no “disfluencies”, like starting with “um”.

Hi, That’s an interesting question. One way some authors do this . . . is to speak their text. There is software (Dragon seems to be the most popular) that converts sounds into text. I’m old-school I’ll type and will abbreviate things like will to ‘I’ll’ etc as I type. Have a think . . . speak or type? Wishing you every success, Paul
